odl.discr package¶

Submodules¶

odl.discr.discretization module¶

odl.discr.discretization.uniform_discretization(parent, rnimpl, shape=None, order=u'C')[source]¶

Creates an discretization of space parent using rn as the underlying representation.

order indicates the order data is stored in, ‘C’-order is the default numpy order, also called row major.

odl.discr.grid module¶

Sparse implementations of n-dimensional sampling grids.

Sampling grids are collections of points in an n-dimensional coordinate space with a certain structure which is exploited to minimize storage.

Class name Description
TensorGrid The points are given as the tensor product of n coordinate vectors, i.e. all possible n-tuples where the i-th coordinate is from the i-th coordinate vector.
RegularGrid A variant of a tensor grid where the entries of each coordinate vector are equispaced. This type of grid can be represented by three n-dimensional vectors shape, center and stride.
class odl.discr.grid.RegularGrid(shape, center=None, stride=None)[source]¶

Bases: odl.discr.grid.TensorGrid

An n-dimensional tensor grid with equidistant coordinates.

This is a sparse representation of an n-dimensional grid defined as the tensor product of n coordinate vectors with equidistant nodes. The grid points are calculated according to the rule

x_j = center + (j - (shape-1)/2 * stride)

with elementwise addition and multiplication. Note that the division is a true division (no rounding), thus if there is an axis with an even number of nodes, the center is not a grid point.

Name Type Description
coord_vectors numpy.ndarray tuple Vectors containing the grid point coordinates per axis
dim int Number of axes
shape int tuple Number of grid points per axis
center numpy.ndarray The grid’s symmetry center (not necessarily a grid point)
stride numpy.ndarray Vector pointing from x[j] to x[j + (1,...,1)]
ntotal int Total number of grid points
min numpy.ndarray Grid point with minimal coordinates in each axis
max numpy.ndarray Grid point with maximal coordinates in each axis
Signature Return type Description
equals(other, tol=0.0) boolean Test if other is a grid with the same points up to a tolerance of tol per point. Equivalent to self == other for tol==0.0.
contains(point, tol=0.0) boolean Test if point is a grid point with tolerance tol. Equivalent to point in self for tol==0.
is_subgrid(other, tol=0.0) boolean Test if other is contained with tolerance tol per point.
insert(grid, index) RegularGrid Insert grid before index.
points(order=’C’) numpy.ndarray All grid points in a single array
corners (order=’C’) numpy.ndarray The corner points in a single array
meshgrid (sparse=True) numpy.ndarray tuple Efficient grid for function evaluation (see numpy.meshgrid)
convex_hull() IntervalProd The “inner” of the grid, a rectangular box.
center¶

The center of the grid. Not necessarily a grid point.

>>> rg = RegularGrid((2, 3), [-1, 1], [1, 2])
>>> rg.center
array([-1.,  1.])
insert(grid, index)[source]¶

Insert another regular grid before the given index.

The given grid (dimension m) is inserted into the current one (dimension n) before the given index, resulting in a new RegularGrid of dimension n + m. Note that no changes are made in-place.

grid : RegularGrid
The grid to be inserted.
index : Integral
The index of the dimension before which grid is to be inserted. Must fulfill 0 <= index <= dim.
newgrid : RegularGrid
The enlarged grid
>>> rg1 = RegularGrid((1, 3), [-1, 0], [2, 0.5])
>>> rg2 = RegularGrid(7, -3, 6)
>>> rg1.insert(rg2, 1)
RegularGrid([1, 7, 3], [-1.0, -3.0, 0.0], [2.0, 6.0, 0.5])
is_subgrid(other, tol=0.0)[source]¶

Test if this grid is contained in another grid.

tol : float
Allow deviations up to this number in absolute value per coordinate vector entry.
>>> rg = RegularGrid((3, 4), [-1, 1], [1, 2])
>>> rg.coord_vectors
(array([-2., -1.,  0.]), array([-2.,  0.,  2.,  4.]))
>>> rg_sub = RegularGrid((2, 2), [-1, 1], [2, 2])
>>> rg_sub.coord_vectors
(array([-2.,  0.]), array([ 0.,  2.]))
>>> rg_sub.is_subgrid(rg)
True

Fuzzy check is also possible. Note that the tolerance still applies to the coordinate vectors, not ‘stride’ and ‘center’.

>>> rg_sub = RegularGrid((2, 4), [-1, 1], [2.01, 2.01])
>>> # stride error accumulates towards the endpoints
>>> rg_sub.coord_vectors[1]
array([-2.015, -0.005,  2.005,  4.015])
>>> rg_sub.is_subgrid(rg, tol=0.01)
False
>>> rg_sub.is_subgrid(rg, tol=0.02)
True
stride¶

The step per axis between two neighboring grid points.

>>> rg = RegularGrid((2, 3), [-1, 1], [1, 2])
>>> rg.stride
array([ 1.,  2.])
class odl.discr.grid.TensorGrid(*coord_vectors)[source]¶

Bases: odl.space.set.Set

An n-dimensional tensor grid.

This is a sparse representation of a collection of n-dimensional points defined by the tensor product of n coordinate vectors.

Example: x = (x_1, x_2), y = (y_1, y_2, y_3, y_4), z = (z_1, z_2, z_3). The resulting grid consists of all possible combinations p = (x_i, y_j, z_k), hence 2 * 4 * 3 = 24 points in total.

Name Type Description
coord_vectors numpy.ndarray tuple Vectors containing the grid point coordinates per axis
dim int Number of axes
shape int tuple Number of grid points per axis
ntotal int Total number of grid points
min numpy.ndarray Grid point with minimal coordinates in each axis
max numpy.ndarray Grid point with maximal coordinates in each axis
Signature Return type Description
contains(point, tol=0.0) boolean Test if point is a grid point with tolerance tol. Equivalent to point in self for tol==0.
convex_hull() IntervalProd The “inner” of the grid, a rectangular box.
corners (order=’C’) numpy.ndarray The corner points in a single array
equals(other, tol=0.0) boolean Test if other is a grid with the same points up to a tolerance of tol per point. Equivalent to self == other for tol==0.0.
insert(other, index) TensorGrid Insert other before index.
is_subgrid(other, tol=0.0) boolean Test if other is contained with tolerance tol per point.
meshgrid (sparse=True) numpy.ndarray tuple Efficient grid for function evaluation (see numpy.meshgrid)
points(order=’C’) numpy.ndarray All grid points in a single array
contains(other, tol=0.0)[source]¶

Test if other belongs to this grid.

other : array-like or float
The object to test for membership in this grid
tol : float
Allow deviations up to this number in absolute value per vector entry.
>>> g = TensorGrid([0, 1], [-1, 0, 2])
>>> g.contains([0, 0])
True
>>> [0, 0] in g  # equivalent
True
>>> g.contains([0.1, -0.1])
False
>>> g.contains([0.1, -0.1], tol=0.15)
True
convex_hull()[source]¶

The “inner” of the grid, an IntervalProd.

The convex hull of a set is the union of all line segments between points in the set. For a tensor grid, it is the interval product given by the extremal coordinates.

None

chull : IntervalProd

>>> g = TensorGrid([-1, 0, 3], [2, 4], [5], [2, 4, 7])
>>> ch = g.convex_hull()
>>> ch.begin
array([-1.,  2.,  5.,  2.])
>>> ch.end
array([ 3.,  4.,  5.,  7.])
coord_vectors¶

The coordinate vectors of the grid.

corners(order=u'C')[source]¶

The corner points of the grid in a single array.

order : ‘C’ or ‘F’
The ordering of the axes in which the corners appear in the output.
out : numpy.ndarray
The size of the array is 2^m x dim, where m is the number of non-degenerate axes, i.e. the corners are stored as rows.
>>> g = TensorGrid([0, 1], [-1, 0, 2])
>>> g.corners()
array([[ 0., -1.],
       [ 0.,  2.],
       [ 1., -1.],
       [ 1.,  2.]])
>>> g.corners(order='F')
array([[ 0., -1.],
       [ 1., -1.],
       [ 0.,  2.],
       [ 1.,  2.]])
dim¶

The dimension of the grid.

element()[source]¶

An arbitrary element, the minimum coordinates.

equals(other, tol=0.0)[source]¶

Test if this grid is equal to another grid.

Return True if all coordinate vectors are equal (up to the given tolerance), otherwise False.

tol : float
Allow deviations up to this number in absolute value per vector entry.
>>> g1 = TensorGrid([0, 1], [-1, 0, 2])
>>> g2 = TensorGrid([-0.1, 1.1], [-1, 0.1, 2])
>>> g1.equals(g2)
False
>>> g1 == g2  # equivalent
False
>>> g1.equals(g2, tol=0.15)
True
insert(other, index)[source]¶

Insert another grid before the given index.

The given grid (dimension m) is inserted into the current one (dimension n) before the given index, resulting in a new TensorGrid of dimension n + m. Note that no changes are made in-place.

other : TensorGrid, float or array-like
The grid to be inserted. A float or array a is treated as TensorGrid(a).
index : Integral
The index of the dimension before which grid is to be inserted. Must fulfill 0 <= index <= dim.
newgrid : TensorGrid
The enlarged grid
>>> g1 = TensorGrid([0, 1], [-1, 2])
>>> g2 = TensorGrid([1], [-0.1, 1.1])
>>> g1.insert(g2, 1)
TensorGrid([0.0, 1.0], [1.0], [-0.1, 1.1], [-1.0, 2.0])
is_subgrid(other, tol=0.0)[source]¶

Test if this grid is contained in another grid.

other : TensorGrid
The other grid which is supposed to contain this grid
tol : float
Allow deviations up to this number in absolute value per coordinate vector entry.
>>> g = TensorGrid([0, 1], [-1, 0, 2])
>>> g_sub = TensorGrid([0], [-1, 2])
>>> g_sub.is_subgrid(g)
True
>>> g_sub = TensorGrid([0.1], [-1.05, 2.1])
>>> g_sub.is_subgrid(g)
False
>>> g_sub.is_subgrid(g, tol=0.15)
True
max¶

Vector containing the maximal coordinates per axis.

>>> g = TensorGrid([1, 2, 5], [-2, 1.5, 2])
>>> g.max
array([ 5., 2.])
meshgrid(sparse=True)[source]¶

A grid suitable for function evaluation.

sparse : boolean, optional
If True, the grid is not ‘fleshed out’ to save memory.

meshgrid : tuple of numpy.ndarray’s

numpy.meshgrid (we use indexing=’ij’ and copy=True)

>>> g = TensorGrid([0, 1], [-1, 0, 2])
>>> x, y = g.meshgrid()
>>> x
array([[ 0.],
       [ 1.]])
>>> y
array([[-1.,  0.,  2.]])

Easy function evaluation via broadcasting:

>>> x**2 - y**2
array([[-1.,  0., -4.],
       [ 0.,  1., -3.]])

Alternatively, the grids can be ‘fleshed out’, using significantly more memory

>>> x, y = g.meshgrid(sparse=False)
>>> x
array([[ 0.,  0.,  0.],
       [ 1.,  1.,  1.]])
>>> y
array([[-1.,  0.,  2.],
       [-1.,  0.,  2.]])
>>> x**2 - y**2
array([[-1.,  0., -4.],
       [ 0.,  1., -3.]])
min¶

Vector containing the minimal coordinates per axis.

>>> g = TensorGrid([1, 2, 5], [-2, 1.5, 2])
>>> g.min
array([ 1., -2.])
ntotal¶

The total number of grid points.

points(order=u'C')[source]¶

All grid points in a single array.

order : ‘C’ or ‘F’
The ordering of the axes in which the points appear in the output.
points : numpy.ndarray
The size of the array is ntotal x dim, i.e. the points are stored as rows.
>>> g = TensorGrid([0, 1], [-1, 0, 2])
>>> g.points()
array([[ 0., -1.],
       [ 0.,  0.],
       [ 0.,  2.],
       [ 1., -1.],
       [ 1.,  0.],
       [ 1.,  2.]])
>>> g.points(order='F')
array([[ 0., -1.],
       [ 1., -1.],
       [ 0.,  0.],
       [ 1.,  0.],
       [ 0.,  2.],
       [ 1.,  2.]])
shape¶

The number of grid points per axis.

Module contents¶

Discretizations in ODL.

Module name Description
discretization Discretizations of vector spaces and more general sets
grid Sparse representations of sampling grids
